text: And then the ink/iconography cognoscente were like, nah, probably a Maltese Cross. And Talia deleted the original tweet out of concern for clarity and the feelings of Mr. Maltese Cross. Why leave the speculation hanging if it went nowhere?
author: beyerstein

text: She didn't accuse him of being a Nazi, she just asked if other people thought that his elbow tattoo looked like an Iron Cross. TBH, I was thinking the exact same thing and I remember other people tweeting about the surprising resemblance that day.
author: beyerstein

text: Talia's question was utterly harmless and I'm distressed to see progressive journalists and academics of good will describing this tweet as an error on Talia's part, when she was wholly the victim of an utterly disingenuous smear campaign by the right.
author: beyerstein

text: It was a tweet, not a feature. She asked whether people thought his tattoo looked like an Iron Cross. To the uninitiated eye, it did. Then more knowledgeable tattoo people were like, nope, that's probably a Malta cross.

text: Sometimes the answer to a tough question is "no." That doesn't give license to pounced on the journalist who asked. Although the right wing wants to make that the norm.
author: beyerstein

text: Calling Talia's tweet a "mistake" is legitimizing the entirely bad faith right wing backlash that was unleashed upon her. It's the first step to making tough questions unspeakable.
author: beyerstein

text: It wasn't even a mistake. It was a question: Does this tattoo look like an Iron Cross? That's the kind that journalists on the far-right beat are supposed to ask.

author: beyerstein

text: Talia didn't make a journalistic mistake. She asked if an agent's tattoo resembled an Iron Cross. That's an entirely legitimate question for a reporter on the far right beat & very topical considering the infiltration problems law enforcement has had had lately.

text: That, too. But as long as self-driving cars depend on people to take the wheel in emergencies, decaying driving skills will affect the safety of self-driving cars, too.

text: Are you seriously going to argue that someone who's watching a movie is in a good position to take the wheel in an emergency? This has already happened more than once.
author: beyerstein

text: It's a problem that recurs whenever systems are automated. It's a problem for anesthesiologists and airline pilots. If highly trained and passionate professionals have problems snapping into manual override, it's likely to be worse for amateurs on the road watching The Voice.

text: Self-driving cars are only going to get less safe as people fall out of the habit of driving. Driving is not something you want to do only in life-or-death emergencies. Skills decay.
author: beyerstein

text: Today's self-driving cars are the worst of both worlds because the user has nothing to do but remain vigilant. Without the grounding effects of driving the car, the chances of someone being ready to snap to attention and take decisive action in a life of death scenario are bad.

text: For example, my partner runs a big band at an Ivy League university and he sees first hand that these kids are not coming to the school as professional level musicians in any sense of the word.

text: It's also empirically false that most Ivy League students have professional level skills in their areas of expertise. Rare prodigies in some disciplines do, but it's not the norm.

text: In narrative nonfiction, "show don't tell" means roughly the same thing as it does in fiction, except the scene/details have to be real. But not all journalism uses scenes or vignettes the way narrative nonfiction does.

text: It's the difference between saying "white supremacist gunman" (which could be construed as editorializing) vs. listing the gunman's white supremacist CV (which is evidence from which the reader can draw the conclusion that he's a white supremacist).
author: beyerstein

text: In journalism, "show don't tell" means that you should go with rich, specific detail "A 27-year-old white male named XYZ from Christchurch, who belonged to the following hate groups, etc, etc" instead of "A white supremacist gunman."
